title: 108_hr4550
content: The Act is titled the "Safe, Efficient, Coordinated, Unified, Revitalized, Enhanced Visa Waiver Act" and requires visa waiver participants to electronically submit biographical information. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish an electronic system for visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information before entering the US. The system must provide an electronic response within 30 minutes regarding the alien's eligibility. The system must electronically determine the eligibility of an alien to enter the US as a nonimmigrant visitor within 30 minutes. Carriers and corporations must electronically inquire about the alien's eligibility before embarkation. The system described in section 217(a)(5) of the Act allows for electronic inquiries about an alien's eligibility for admission without a visa, with a 90-second response time. The system must be deployed promptly after the Act's enactment, and a fee will be charged to cover its costs. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish this fee, ensuring full cost recovery. Consultation with the Secretary is required for system development. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a fee for aliens to cover the costs of the system. Consultation with a private sector group is required for system development. SEC. 3. CHANGE TO REQUIREMENT FOR READERS AND SCANNERS AT PORTS OF ENTRY. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act requires the installation of equipment and software at all ports of entry into the United States for biometric comparison and authentication of visas, travel documents, and passports issued to aliens by specific deadlines. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act mandates the installation of equipment and software at all U.S. ports of entry for biometric comparison and authentication of passports issued to aliens. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act mandates technology standard implementation by 2005 and includes a limited good faith waiver provision. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act includes a provision for a limited good faith waiver allowing the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant up to 2 extensions for countries making progress towards meeting passport requirements. Each extension can be up to 6 months. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant up to 2 extensions for countries making progress towards meeting passport requirements, each extension not exceeding 6 months. Factors considered include the country's efforts and programs to meet the requirements by specific deadlines. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act requires countries to have a program in place to meet passport requirements by specific deadlines. The Secretary of Homeland Security will issue reports on countries' progress, with an initial report due by October 26, 2005, and a final report due by April 25, 2006. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, will issue an initial report on countries' progress in meeting passport requirements by October 26, 2005, and a final report by April 25, 2006. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Section 303 of the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act is amended to replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security".
